Award.AwardTitle: Nanoscale Fluctuations and Responses in Complex Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract: In this project we will use techniques developed in our lab, and by others, based on atomic-force microscopy (AFM) to probe local dielectric and mechanical fluctuations and responses on nanometer length scales. These will be applied to several materials with the objective of investigating the fundamental physics of the glass transition, non-equilibrium statistical physics, and nanophysics of materials. The proposed work will include the following three main components: (a) Nanoscale spatio-temporal dynamics will be studied in glassy materials in a search for growing dynamical correlation length scales, which play a dominant role in leading glass transition theories; (b) Measurement of both fluctuations and responses will allow us to test the validity of the global and local fluctuation-dissipation-relation (FDR) in equilibrium and out-of equilibrium in various materials; and (c) Nanodielectric spectroscopy will be used to study near-surface polymer dynamics in polymers and polymer blends. This international collaboration, will exchange U.S. undergraduate international co-op students and other researchers with the DIPC in Spain. They will receive invaluable international experience and training in nanosciences. Development of a reliable method for nanodielectric spectroscopy in particular would have a broad impact on the field of polymer materials science.

Non-technical Abstract: In the coming years, our economy will depend heavily on high-tech innovations, particularly in nanotechnology, information technology, and renewable energy. International cooperation may be beneficial in many cases. Both solar and fuel-cell technologies rely strongly on advanced, nanostructured polymeric materials. Such industries are have an increasing need to understand and predict material properties on nanometer length scales (a row of 5 to 10 atoms). Researchers are increasingly aware of the importance of variations of material properties with position or time, on the nanoscale. Advances in our ability to explore local properties in these materials makes it possible to gain a deeper understanding and better control of these properties and the physics of complex materials. In this project new nanodielectric imaging and spectroscopy techniques will be used to probe property variations in nano-structured materials such as polymer blends. This project will exchange U.S. undergraduate international co-op students and other researchers with a Spanish lab in order to facilitate collaborative projects and to exchange information, materials and skills between the labs. Students will receive invaluable international experience and training in nano-sciences. Development of a reliable method for nanodielectric spectroscopy in particular would have a broad impact on the field of polymer materials science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research in this project was focused on microscopic (nanometer scale) structure and dynamics in various polymeric materials. Some of these materials are poorly understood yet are very important for the development of alternative energy or new medical technologies, such as fuel cells membranes and nanoparticles used in nanomedicine.  An important recent result was our discovery that an established principle in statistical physics, the fluctuation-dissipation-relation, was applicable, with modification, to situations which it was not originally intended, namely non-equilibrium systems which are ubiquitous in nature and living systems. In this instance, the non-equilibrium system was a polymer material heated into a rubbery state, and suddenly and rapidly cooled to a solid state.  In this case we found that the fluctuation-dissipation-relation could be applied, but with a higher effective temperature than is measured with a standard thermometer.  This result had long been predicted, but the precise form of the modification was found and used to discriminate between different theories of the glass transition.

We further developed methods that we pioneered for studying nanoscale dipolar and ion dynamics in thin polymeric materials. Insulating materials such as polymer films have electric charges in the form of ions or dipoles that can move a small amount in response to electric fields, for example in capacitors. The methods allow us to image and study, on nanometer length scales, the motions or mobility of these charges. The techniques have been adopted by six or more national or international research groups, some through collaboration with us. These groups have applied the methods to various other polymer science problems.

In this project we used the methods to investigate the behavior of  polymer nanoparticles (NP) which are spherical particles as small as 15 nm ion diameter. We found that we were able, for the first time, to study the dynamics or mobility of molecules in individual nanoparticles, as they undergo a glass transition from a rubbery to a solid state. We found that compared with bulk polymer material, the behavior of polymer chains within NP are considerably changed and sped-up. The changes observed varied considerably with the size of NP and could be explained in terms of enhanced surface mobility and the deformations as a result of interaction with the substrate surface.

In another project we studied polymeric membranes used in fuel cell applications, in collaboration with NIST. In fuel cells H+ ions must pass through a selectively porous membrane, a proton-exchange-membrane (PEM), which blocks other ions or electrons. Therefore electrons are forced into a wire and an external circuit in order to rejoin the H+  to complete the process of combining with oxygen to form water. Electric power is generated as a result, but the efficiency of these devices is hampered by energy losses within the membrane. So it is essential to understand the microscopic structure and ion dynamics with these materials. We developed methods to study and image hydrogen ion (H+) dynamics on very small length scales within thin PEM  materials. We showed that the dynamics was comparable to that found on macroscopic scales and that ions were active in a hopping process even when the material was quite dehydrated. This would be the situation in more efficient fuel cells to be developed. We hope to apply these methods to ultra-thin PEM films prepared in different ways that make it possible to study structure of membrane pores and the mechanisms of efficient transport of protons.
